confession.seduction_date: after father's death (approximately 10 years before trial)
confession.seduction_context: After father's execution, land forfeit to M. d'Etival. Was allowed to take land back on payment of entry fine but had difficulty paying. Napnel appeared and seduced him, giving purse of money which turned out to be oak leaves.
sabbat_activities: dancing back to back to sound of drums, violins and flutes

testimony.quarrel_subject: dispute about right to some water behind houses
testimony.threat_quote: qu'ils ne luy payoient la garde de leur veaux, mais qu'ils la payeroient en un autre endroict qu'ils ne s'en donneroient de garde

witnesses.name: Alizon
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: wife of Claudon Demenge Grand Didier

testimony.threat_quote: qu'il mengeoit bien ce vieulx diable de cheval

testimony.quarrel_subject: possible dissatisfaction with load of wood
daughter asked to buy cheese, was refused
proposed to share animals for ploughing, husband preferred arrangement with Jean Gerard

witnesses.name: Halby femme Demenge Colas Gerard
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: mother of Claudon Demenge Grand Didier

testimony.quarrel_subject: horse repeatedly damaged his field of oats
refused to sell him a pig
refused to take his horse to cart wood (horse too lazy)
testimony.threat_quote: qu'il s'en aille doncque que dieu luy soit en aide, et se donne bien de garde qu'il ne soit blessé

testimony.quarrel_subject: refused to sell him a horse, then accused complained about damage done by witness's animals
accused wanted delivery of wood after buying 'heritages de menantie', witness delayed until approved by Mr d'Etival

timeline.subject: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
timeline.details: Procureur d'office asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to torture

timeline.subject: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
timeline.details: Given thumbscrews, rack, and tortillons; would not confess, only admitted stealing wood

timeline.subject: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
timeline.details: Voluntary confession - said master Napnel had been in his throat preventing confession

timeline.subject: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
timeline.details: Continuation of confession, named accomplices at sabbat

accomplices_named.name: Marguitte femme Simon Jacot
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat (daughter of Claudon Jean Perrin)

prior_accusations.context: Formal accuser who initiated the trial

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
notable_quotes.french: qu'ils ne luy payoient la garde de leur veaux, mais qu'ils la payeroient en un autre endroict qu'ils ne s'en donneroient de garde
notable_quotes.english: they did not pay him for guarding their calves, but they would pay him in another place they would not think of
notable_quotes.context: Threat to wife of Claudon Demenge Grand Didier before cow died

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
notable_quotes.french: qu'il mengeoit bien ce vieulx diable de cheval
notable_quotes.english: that old devil of a horse eats well
notable_quotes.context: Comment about Colas Andreu's horse before it died

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
notable_quotes.french: que le plus jeune et dernier devenu malade, racheteroit le plus grand, et mouroit
notable_quotes.english: that the youngest and last to become sick would redeem the older one, and would die
notable_quotes.context: Prediction about Marguitte femme Colas Andreu's sick children

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
notable_quotes.french: qu'il n'y venoit pour y faire du mal
notable_quotes.english: that he did not come there to do harm

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
notable_quotes.english: it would eat a bot (possibly 'beating' or similar punishment)
notable_quotes.context: Threat about horse that repeatedly damaged his oat field

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
notable_quotes.french: qu'il s'en aille doncque que dieu luy soit en aide, et se donne bien de garde qu'il ne soit blessé
notable_quotes.english: let it go then, may God help it, and take good care that it not be injured
notable_quotes.context: Threat to Colas Jean Andreu about his horse

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
notable_quotes.french: que cela estoit vray, mais que peult estre n'en avoient ils point de necessité
notable_quotes.english: that it was true, but that perhaps they had no need of it
notable_quotes.context: Cryptic response to Jean Simon's comment about only needing seven feet of earth at death

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudonné Jean Thierion
notable_quotes.french: que c'est une grande pitié de veoir tant de pauvre gens ainsy abusé du diable. Adjoustant que ausdits sabatz les riches sont tousjours les plus prisés et assis au hault bout, proche des maitres, et les pauvres n'ont que le reste des riches, et n'y sont beaucoup prisée
notable_quotes.english: that it is a great pity to see so many poor people thus abused by the devil. Adding that at the said sabbats the rich are always the most valued and sit at the high end, close to the masters, and the poor have only the leftovers of the rich, and are not much valued there
notable_quotes.context: Comment about social hierarchy at sabbat during confession

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudatte (mother-in-law)
notable_quotes.french: maulx dire les pere et mere qui l'avoient mis au monde, ad cause qu'il avoit tant de maulx de vivre
notable_quotes.english: cursed the father and mother who had brought him into the world, because he had so much trouble making a living
notable_quotes.context: Reporting accused's complaints about his difficult life

relationships.evidence_text: living with her brother-in-law Colas Andreu
illness of her son Claudon Demenge Grand Didier

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over water rights behind houses. Accused had difficulty paying entry fine for father's forfeited land after execution. Stole wood from neighbors (multiple witnesses). Several disputes over economic transactions (selling animals, delivering wood, sharing plough animals). Complained about difficulty making a living after father turned him out for being reputed a witch. Comment about social hierarchy at sabbat (poor not valued, rich sit at high table) suggests acute awareness of economic marginalization.

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: dispute about right to some water behind houses
accused's children guarded witness's cows, threat about payment

harms_catalog.harm_description: so seriously ill expected to die; accused visited and placed hand in bed, illness taken away

accused proposed sharing animals for ploughing, husband preferred arrangement with Jean Gerard

harms_catalog.harm_description: became ill and languished for a year

refused to sell him a pig, accused was angry

economic_hardship_indicators: accused had difficulty paying entry fine for father's forfeited land
accused complained about 'tant de maulx de vivre' (so much trouble making a living)
accused stole logs from neighbors to give children warmth
comment about poor people being abused by devil and not valued at sabbat

prior_legal_disputes.description: Stole logs from Laurent Jean Laurent, which he was obliged to restore
Took goods from church in val de Saint Dié, for which he was 'bien escoutengé'

legal_context.redress_outcome: Multiple witnesses testified he was called witch publicly without seeking reparation

hearsay_chains.reporter: Alizon femme Claudon Demenge Grand Didier
hearsay_chains.content: mother-in-law warned accused of suspicions, he said 'quelque sorciere' caused deaths
if he was witch he killed Claudon Demenge Grand Didier's cow; if arrested would say enough 'pour le faire descombrer'
told him he was a witch like his father
he took goods from church in val de Saint Dié

emotional_state_notes: would not renounce devil during first interrogation
explained delay in confessing by saying master Napnel had been in his throat preventing him

third_parties.name: Claudon Jean Perrin
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: father of Marguitte femme Simon Jacot
third_parties.context: Executed 18 May 1611; had accused Dieudonné Jean Thierion before his execution

third_parties.name: Jean Thirion
third_parties.context: Executed as witch at Saint Dié some 10-12 years earlier; appeared as ghost to accused after execution

third_parties.name: Claudatte
third_parties.context: Married at Clemecy; told accused he was witch like his father

third_parties.context: Leg broken in strange accident after accused's threat; now deceased ('late')

third_parties.name: Colas Ferry
third_parties.context: Rozemand du Renty was in his service when injured

third_parties.name: Jehennon Grand Didier

third_parties.context: Claudon Fallayeux preferred ploughing arrangement with him over accused

third_parties.name: Jean Claudon Thirion
third_parties.context: Fence dispute with accused's father over garden and pear-tree

third_parties.name: M. d'Etival

third_parties.name: Napnel
third_parties.context: Devil who seduced accused; gave purse of money that turned to oak leaves

extraction_metadata.notes: Trial has very clear pattern: accused is son of executed witch, struggled economically after father's land was forfeited, had reputation issues. Multiple economic disputes (water rights, animal sharing, sales, wood delivery) preceded alleged harms. Nearly all harms are animal deaths (horses, cows, pigs, calf) with tight temporal clustering after quarrels (often within a week or days). Notable features: (1) accused's comment about social hierarchy at sabbat reflecting class consciousness; (2) resisted torture but confessed voluntarily next day; (3) multiple theft incidents (logs, church goods) suggesting genuine economic desperation; (4) did not seek legal redress when called witch publicly (unusual); (5) ghost story about father appearing after execution. Economic status coded as 'poor' based on: difficulty paying entry fine, stealing wood 'to give children warmth', complaints about difficulty making living, father turned him out, and sabbat comment about poor people. Father's execution approximately 1602-1604; accused executed 1614. Language region: french (all names, testimony in French). No healing practices mentioned. Formal accuser Claudon Jean Perrin already executed by time of this trial (1611), so unclear exact mechanism of accusation initiation - may have been named posthumously in earlier confession.
